captions.text: DOLPHINS ARE GETTING HIGH, MAYBE.
HI I'M CATIE WAYNE AND THIS IS ANIMALIST NEWS.

SO THE CREATORS OF A NEW BBC DOCUMENTARY ENTITLED
"DOLPHINS: SPY IN THE POD" HAS DISCOVERED

SOMETHING PRETTY INTERESTING.
DOLPHINS GET HIGH.

CAMERAS CLEVERLY DISGUISED AS FISH CAPTURED
FOOTAGE OF DOLPHINS LIGHTLY CHEWING A PUFFERFISH,

PASSING IT AROUND, AND THEN ENTERING A TRANCE-LIKE
STATE.

ROB PILLEY, THE PRODUCER OF THE SERIES STATED
THAT "AFTER THEY CHEWED THE PUFFER GENTLY,"

THEY BEGAN "HANGING AROUND WITH THEIR NOSES
AT THE SURFACE AS IF FASCINATED BY THEIR OWN
REFLECTION."
THAT IS HILARIOUS.

BUT AUTHOR OF DISCOVER'S "SCIENCE SUSHI"
BLOG CHRISTIE WILCOX THINKS OTHERWISE. YOU

SEE, TETRODOTOXIN, THE POISON THAT PUFFER FISH SECRETE
WHEN THEY FEEL THREATENED IS NOT A NARCOTIC

DRUG. IN VERY LOW DOSES, IT CAN CAUSE NUMBNESS,
OR A TINGLING EFFECT, BUT IT DOES NOT ALTER
ANY STATE OF PERCEPTION OR ENHANCE SENSATIONS.

BUT THIS IS ONLY IN SMALL DOSES, IF CONSUMED
IN HIGHER AMOUNTS, THE TOXIN IS VERY DEADLY.

TO SUGGEST THAT THE DOLPHINS ARE GETTING HIGH
OFF OF THESE PUFFER FISH SUGGESTS THAT THE

DOLPHINS KNOW EXACTLY HOW LONG TO CHEW ON
THE PUFFER FISH BEFORE IT GETS DANGEROUS.

THESE ARE VERY INTELLIGENT, CURIOUS ANIMALS
WE'RE TALKING ABOUT SO IT'S NOT ENTIRELY

OUT OF THE QUESTION, BUT IT'S A BIT OF A
STRETCH.

WHAT DO YOU GUYS THINK? ARE THESE DOLPHINS
GETTING HIGH, OR IS THIS JUST A CASE OF A

CURIOUS ANIMAL PLAYING WITH A STRANGE FISH?
LET ME KNOW IN THE COMMENTS BELOW.

IF YOU WANT TO READ MORE ABOUT THIS, THERE
ARE CLICKABLE LINKS IN THE DOOBLY DOO. DON'T

FORGET TO CHECK OUT THESE VIDEOS OVER HERE,
SUBSCRIBE DOWN HERE. WHILE YOU'RE DOING
I LOVE YOU ALL, AND I'LL SEE YOU TOMORROW!

comments.text:
It's no secret that various mammals intentionally eat things that alter 
their consciousness. Puffer fish toxin is said to produce a pleasant 
alteration of consciousness when taken in low doses and diners in Japanese 
restaurants where puffer fish are served report that they may feel such a 
"high" from a tiny trace of puffer fish toxin that may remain in their 
meal. However the diffrerence between a dose that gets you high and a dose 
that kills you indeed be difficult to judge. Maybe this explains some of 
the beached sea mammals that show up now and then without any explanation 
as to how they died?﻿

comments.text:
Yeah...they need to test this. Saying that pufferfish have the same effect 
on dolphins as on humans is invalid. Mostly because we are adapted to land 
and they to water, so shouldn't there be different effects for various 
chemicals? Even from jumping from one land mammal to another you get 
different effects: some mammals are immune or resistant to snake venom, 
others are allergic to chocolate,etc etc. Different species bodies react to 
chemicals differently, we shouldn't come to conclusions without testing. ﻿

In parts of Asia these pufferfish are eaten... essentially, to get high, 
despite the fact that if a chef doesn't prepare the dish correctly, there's 
a good chance of dying from having your entire body paralyzed so your lungs 
stop working. So, whoever the author was is wrong - humans eat this solely 
for the sensation it produces, meaning they eat it to get high. Dolphins 
could very well be doing the same.

I was bored one day and decided to research asian pufferfish dishes for a 
few hours, lol.﻿

comments.text:
Dogs do NOT get any kind of numbing, tingling or narcotic effect from 
theobromine ... Not at all. It's just an allergy & they have an 
anaphylactic reaction. Basically they swell up & suffocate. Like someone 
who is allergic to bee stings or peanuts.
comments.author: Katie Dubbs

comments.text:
A valid point. However I think you're confusing immune system responses 
with perceptive responses. When any drug, recreational or otherwise, is 
consumed, the associated changes in perception are not a direct result of 
the consumed chemicals. Instead, (our) brains release a given chemical in 
response to the given chemical, (e.g. serotonin, dopamine, etc...) 
Therefore, a mammal's ability to react to a given substance depends on 
their brain's ability to produce other chemicals. On a side note: the fact 
that chocolate is poisonous to dogs has nothing whatsoever to do with the 
brain, but rather the digestive system.
